The World Health Organization: WHO) has clarified that viruses and the diseases they cause often have different names, and the name of a disease may not necessarily reflect the name of the virus that causes it.
The International Committee on Taxonomy: ICTV) officially named the virus responsible for the COVID-19 pandemic as "severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2)" on February 11, 2020, indicating its genetic relation to the coronavirus responsible for the SARS outbreak in 2003.
On the same day: the WHO announced "COVID-19" as the name of the new disease caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus. The name is a shortening of "coronavirus disease" with the number 19 reflecting the year it was first reported (2019).
The claim that COVID: 19 stands for "Chinese-Originated Viral Infectious Disease" and represents the 19th virus to come out of China is debunked as a false and misleading joke. The name does not indicate any geographical origin of the virus.
